images.copyright: Red-necked grebes in Germany (© Edo van Uchelen/Minden Pictures)
images.title: You might be a red-necked grebe if…
images.caption: Red-necked grebes during breeding season
images.desc: The red-necked grebe has a bit of a split personality—in fact, it only lives up to its name about half the year. Its feathers are not red but brambly brown and gray throughout the winter, when it lives a low-key, quiet life in salt water along North American and European coasts. But just before it migrates to a northerly lake, pond, or swamp for breeding season, the plumage around the grebe's throat turns a distinctive rust-red. Both males and females undergo the plumage change.
